It explains the limitations of a system initially designed to respond to the needs of Colonial America. The course also focuses on individuals' involvement in the criminal justice system, as citizens and as actors, and how that involvement affects the system.

The general course topics include introduction to security; legal aspects, risk assessment, and planning; physical, personnel, and information security; investigations, security applications, and solutions; and homeland security treads and challenges.

The course also discusses how the Internet and information systems support the previous activities.

eac70b7d-186e-4266-9158-299b173469f6.name: Terrorism (CJS 215)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examinations, written papers, and a comprehensive final exam with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.

They’ve studied critical, inductive, and deductive thinking. They’ve demonstrated practical application of evaluation, troubleshooting and problem solving skills.
66bb4069-9ece-47ee-b1d8-7eed93cdcdad.name: Warehouse Business Basics

They’ve studied materials, techniques, and tools required for sketching industrial drawings.

d6e852dc-ae0b-440e-ac62-8d5cb63b032d.name: White Collar Crime (CJS225)

The general course topics include white collar crime; white collar crime in various systems; white collar crime in the economy; and preventing and policing white collar crime.

They can identify sharpening and grinding equipment used in maintaining and servicing tools. They can explain safe and correct use of jacks, hoists, and pullers for lifting.
